revisions.rev:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox uprising | title = 2011 Chinese Protests | image = Jasmine Revolution in China - Beijing 11 02 20 crowd 2.jpg | caption = A large crowd of protesters, journalists, police and spectators gathered in front of a [[McDonalds]] restaurant in [[Wangfujing]], Beijing. | alt = | location = {{flagicon|PRC}} People's Republic of China | coordinates = | date = 20 February 2011 â 20 March 2011 | time = | timezone = | characteristics = | injuries = 4 journalists | arrests = 35 dissidents, about 25 journalists }} {{ChineseText}}
The '''2011 Chinese pro-democracy protests'''<ref name="time_22feb" /> refer to weekly street actions in over a dozen cities in mainland [[People's Republic of China|China]] starting on 20 February 2011, inspired by and named after the [[Tunisian Revolution#Naming|Jasmine Revolution in Tunisia]];<ref name="FT_weeklydemosPRC" /><ref name="AP_27Febplans"/> the actions that took and take place at protest sites, and response by the Chinese government to the calls and action.<ref name="AP_27Febplans" /><ref name="LATimes_PRC_26Feb" />
Initially, organisers recommended shouting slogans on 20 February. After participants and journalists having been beaten and arrested, organisers urged a change to "strolling" on 27 February in order to minimize police reactions while sustaining the cycle of actions.<ref name="AP_27Febplans"/> On this 2nd protest day, the number of protesters could not be determined. Protest and/or official actions were noted in only two out of the thirteen suggested cities, it was even less clear who were protestors and who were just regular strollers. Notwithstanding, police mounted a "huge"<ref name="wsj_engle_beaten" /> security operation on both 20 and 27 February. Media sources reported that on 27 February, at least four foreign journalists, including Stephen Engle of Bloomberg News and a BBC cameraman, had been beaten by plain-clothes security officers in Beijing.<ref name="wsj_engle_beaten" /><ref name="BBC_grammaticas_bashed" /><ref name="BBC_grammaticas_bashed" /><ref name="CNN_JoKent" /> Police arrested protesters. In Shanghai, protestors successfully prevented police from making an arrest and were able to air their slogans with foreign journalists.<ref name="SCMP_unconventional" /> Since late February, about 35 human rights activists and lawyers were arrested<ref name="AP_27Febplans" /> and five people were charged with [[inciting subversion of state power]].<ref name="LATimes_PRC_26Feb" />
==Protest aims== ===Initial call=== The anonymous call for a 'Jasmine revolution' in China's major cities was made online, first on the [[Boxun.com]] website, run by overseas dissidents, and then on Twitter.<ref name="time_22feb">{{Cite news|last=Ramzy |first=Austin |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2052860,00.html |title=China Cracks Down After 'Jasmine Revolution' Protest Call |work=TIME |accessdate=22 February 2011 |date=21 February 2011}}</ref><ref>AFP via Google. "[http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gdb6d9fdbjbk3XXfkCIHj4X-OSLg?docId=CNG.7a0509e93accafbdfd4785aad6cc3018.441 China web users call for 'Jasmine Revolution']." ''China web users call for 'Jasmine Revolution'.'' Retrieved on 21 February 2011.</ref> The initial call for protest began on 19 February 2011 when 12 to 13 cities were suggested.<ref name="Dw">Dw-world.de. "[http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,14854793,00.html Dw-world.de]." ''ç½ä¼ "èèè±é©å½"ï¼ä¸­å½å½å±å ¨çº¿æå¤ .'' Retrieved on 21 February 2011.</ref> The Boxun.com appeal called for protests to take place each weekend,<ref name="FT_weeklydemosPRC">{{Cite news | first=Kathrin | last=Hille | title='Jasmine revolutionaries' call for weekly China protests | date=23 February 2011 |work=The Financial Times | url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/3ac349d0-3efe-11e0-834e-00144feabdc0,Authorised=false.html?_i_location=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F3ac349d0-3efe-11e0-834e-00144feabdc0.html&_i_referer=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2Fd4fcf4e6-3f6d-11e0-a1ba-00144feabdc0%2CAuthorised%3Dfalse.html%3F_i_location%3Dhttp%253A%252F%252Fwww.ft.com%252Fcms%252Fs%252F0%252Fd4fcf4e6-3f6d-11e0-a1ba-00144feabdc0.html%26_i_referer%3Dhttp%253A%252F%252Fwww.ft.com%252Fhome%252Fuk |accessdate=23 February 2011 |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/5wij5zrEB|archivedate=23 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> arguing that "sustained action will show the Chinese government that its people expect accountability and transparency that doesn't exist under the current one-party system."<ref name="AP_27Febplans"/> {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:20%;"| City ! style="width:20%;"| Province ! style="width:40%;"| Location<ref name="appled">{{cite web| title =ç¶²æ°ç¼åä¸­åèèè±é©å½è§£æ¾è»å´é£ä»¥å¾ |work=Apple Daily |location=Hong Kong | date =2011-02| url =http://hkm.appledaily.com/Home/ShowArticle/d2e01556-bca4-4d6d-bf1d-aef9c3a2f61d | accessdate=21 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wykBEkj9 |archivedate=6 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> |- | Beijing || â || [[McDonald's]] at [[Wangfujing]] |- | [[Changchun]] || Jilin || Culture Square, West Minzhu Street, front door of Corogo supermarket |- | [[Changsha]] || Hunan || Wuyi square, Xinda building front door |- | [[Chengdu]] || Sichuan || Tianfu square, beneath Chairman Mao statue |- | [[Guangzhou]] || Guangdong || People's park Starbucks |- | [[Hangzhou]] || Zhejiang || Wulin square, front door of Hangzhou department store |- | [[Harbin]] || Heilongjiang || Front door of Harbin cinema |- | [[Nanjing]] || Jiangsu || Drum tower square, Xiushui Street, department store front door |- | Shanghai || â || People's square, front door of Peace Cinema |- | [[Shenyang]] || Liaoning || Nanjing-Bei (North Nanjing) Street, front door of [[Kentucky Fried Chicken|KFC]] |- | [[Tianjin]] || â || Beneath the Tianjin drum tower |- | [[Wuhan]] || Hubei || Liberation road, World trade square Mcdonalds front door |- | [[Xi'an]] || Shaanxi || Beida Street (åå¤§), front door of [[Carrefour]] |}
===Protest strategy and tactics=== {{Quote box |title = Rallying cry |quote = We invite every participant to stroll, watch or even just pretend to pass by. As long as you are present, the authoritarian government will be shaking with fear.
|source = Open letter 22 Feb. 2011<ref name="AP_27Febplans"/> |align = right |width = 33% |border = 1px |fontsize = 88% |bgcolor = |style = |title_bg = |title_fnt = |tstyle = |qalign = |qstyle = |quoted = |salign = |sstyle = }} '''A number of slogans were suggested to the protests:'''<ref name="appled" /> {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:50%;"| Translation in English ! style="width:50%;"| Chinese |- | We want food, we want work, we want housing! || æåè¦é£ç©ãæåè¦å·¥ä½ãæåè¦ä½æ¿! |- | We want fairness, we want justice! || æåè¦å ¬å¹³ãæåè¦æ­£ç¾©! |- | Guarantee property rights, protect judicial independence! || ä¿éç§æç¢æ¬ãç¶­è­·å¸æ³ç¨ç«! |- | Initiate change in political reform, end one party dictatorship! (or "Terminate one-party rule"<ref name="SCMP_mealNo3">{{Cite news | first=Shi | last=Jiangtao | title=Fresh call goes out for Beijing 'jasmine' rallies | date=1 March 2011 |work=South China Morning Post |location=Hong Kong | url=http://topics.scmp.com/news/china-news-watch/article/Fresh-call-goes-out-for-Beijing-jasmine-rallies |accessdate=3 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wuvYKGui |archivedate=3 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref>)|| ååæ¿æ²»æ¹é©ãçµæä¸é»¨å°æ¿!<ref name="appled" /> (or åæ­¢ä¸é»¨å°æ¿) |- | Lift restrictions, free the press! || éæ¾å ±ç¦ãæ°èèªç±! |- | [[Ten Thousand Years|Long live]] freedom, long live democracy! || èªç±è¬æ­²ãæ°ä¸»è¬æ­²! |}
On 2 March, organisers declared a three-stage strategy. The first stage would take "a few weeks, a couple of months, a year or even longer"; the second stage would include "holding a jasmine flower and [using] mobile phones or music players to play [the folk song] ''[[Mo Li Hua|Such a Beautiful Jasmine]]''". Organisers declared the third stage as "when the street-walking revolution is irreversible"; it would involve people criticising the government openly and without fear.<ref name="SCMP_unconventional"/>
The media reported a vindication by protest organisers on 2 March saying, "Now China's government clearly shows its horror and fear of the people, as if facing a deadly enemy. A modest amount of people, just by walking, have demonstrated the people's power, and the government's response has revealed its weaknesses to the world."<ref name="SCMP_unconventional">{{Cite news | first=Will | last=Clem | title=The flowering of an unconventional revolution | date=3 March 2011 |work=South China Morning Post |location=Hong Kong | url=http://topics.scmp.com/news/china-news-watch/article/The-flowering-of-an-unconventional-revolution |accessdate=3 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wuxVUdhV |archivedate=3 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref>Ford, Peter (3 Mar 2011) [http://news.yahoo.com/s/csm/20110303/wl_csm/367034 "Report on China's 'Jasmine Revolution'? Not if you want your visa."], ''Christian Science Monitor'', Yahoo! News</ref> For 6 March, protesters were urged to "either gather near fast-food restaurants, take a stroll, or eat at the restaurants, ... [and order] set meal No3 at the McDonald's and the KFC".<ref name="SCMP_mealNo3" />
==February 2011== ===20 February=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:0001.png|thumb|alt=|US ambassador Jon Huntsman, Jr. seen at the Beijing protest site on 20 February]] -->
The Associated Press, reported only "a handful of people" were known to have actively involved in organizing the staging rallies in 13 cities.<ref name="AP_27Febplans"/> The ''Globe and Mail'' reported that the 20 February appeal was answered by 200 people at the Beijing rendezvous. There was a similar protest in Shanghai with about 100 participants.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Canada |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/asia-pacific/china-halts-online-call-for-a-jasmine-revolution/article1914553/ |title=China halts online call for a âjasmine revolutionâ |work=The Globe and Mail |accessdate=22 February 2011 |location=Toronto}}</ref>
An elderly female demonstrator in Shanghai stated: "Our country has no proper legal system, it's a one-party dictatorship, a tyranny, that suppresses the citizens. There is also land eviction. Many people are beaten to death in many land eviction cases."<ref>[http://itn.co.uk/1d1e962f11c62e23239e179b0dd7960b.html "The Chinese authorities have cracked down on a small pro-democracy rally apparently modelled on the protests sweeping the Arab world", ITN News London 2/20/2011]</ref>
The United States Ambassador to China, [[Jon Huntsman, Jr.]], was seen at the protest rendezvous point. Huntsman exchanged a few words with people in Chinese and then his entourage departed the site immediately. US Embassy spokeman Richard Buangan said that Huntsman and family were on their way to a museum and "they immediately left" once they realized what was going on. The [[Atlantic Wire]] reports: "that hasn't stopped nationalist Chinese bloggers from using Huntsman's appearance to drum-up conspiracies of a U.S. plot to destabilize China".<ref name="atlanticwire_huntsman">{{cite web|last=Hudson |first=John |url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/features/view/feature/Spotted-Jon-Hunstman-Goes-Revolutionary-Chic-3247/ |title=Spotted: Jon Hunstman Goes Revolutionary Chic |publisher=The Atlantic Wire |date=23 February 2011 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="bbc_huntsman">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/zhongwen/simp/china/2011/02/110223_us_ambassador_beijing.shtml |title=BBC ä¸­æç½ â ä¸¤å²¸ä¸å° â Âæ´ªåå¹å¨èèè±ç¤ºå¨å°ç¹å±å·§åÂ |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Lizza |first=Ryan |url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/newsdesk/2011/02/the-huntsman-walk.html |title=The Huntsman Walk |work=The New Yorker |date=7 January 2009 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Burr |first=Thomas |url=http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/home/51307448-76/huntsman-china-rally-ambassador.html.csp |title=Huntsman at China rally â by accident |work=The Salt Lake Tribune |date=24 February 2011 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref> {{wide image|Jasmine Revolution in China - Beijing 11 02 20 crowd.jpg|700px|Crowd in front of a McDonald's in Wangfujing on 20 February 2011}}
===27 February=== After the police response to the protests on 20 February, the organizers urged the participants not to shout slogans any more, but simply to stroll silently at the respective protest sites. The call to use "strolling" tactics for the 27 February gatherings was made on the Boxun.com website on 22 February.<ref name="AP_27Febplans"/> Prior to the planned 27 February gathering in front of a McDonald's restaurant in Beijing, authorities installed metal corrugated fencing outside the restaurant and outside the home of [[2010 Nobel Peace Prize|Nobel laureate]] and dissident [[Liu Xiaobo]].<ref name="LATimes_PRC_26Feb" /> Hundreds of uniformed and plain-clothed security staff and volunteers wearing red armbands were pre-emptively stationed at Wangfujing. Their presence disrupted normal shopping and attracted onlookers.<ref name="wsj_engle_beaten"/> Police began to clear the rendezvous area half an hour after the designated assembly time.<ref name="webjiabao_webchat" />
On 27 February, activists in 2 cities â Beijing and Shanghai â out of the 23 originally suggested responded. Seven people were reportedly arrested in Shanghai and police kept reporters, participants and strollers moving. Since the organisers proposed for protesters to just walk by silently to protest, it was impossible to tell who were protesting and who were just regular strollers on the streets.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE71Q0TR20110227?pageNumber=2&virtualBrandChannel=0 |title=China protest call smothered in police blanket |agency=Reuters |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref> The ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' stated, "while several Chinese people were seen having altercations with the police, there were no signs of actual protests."<ref name="wsj_engle_beaten" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,14877405,00.html |title=Chinese police detain German journalists covering protests |publisher=Deutsche Welle |date=24 February 2011 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref>
====Beijing==== Several foreign journalists were physically beaten by the police, with many others physically pushed by the police, their cameras confiscated and footage deleted.<ref name="CNN_JoKent"/> ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' gave an eyewitness account of an incident in Beijing in which [[Bloomberg Television|Bloomberg]] reporter [[Stephen Engle]] was "grabbed by several security officers, pushed to the ground, dragged along by his leg, punched in the head and beaten with a broom handle by a man dressed as street sweeper."<ref name="wsj_engle_beaten">{{Cite news | first=Jeremy | last=Page |coauthors= James T. Areddy | title=China Takes Heavy Hand to Light Protests | date=27 February 2011 |work=Wall Street Journal | url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703933404576170152436754150.html?mod=googlenews_wsj |accessdate=27 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5woqrtvvD |archivedate=27 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> The Foreign Correspondents' Club of China denounced the attack on Engle, and called for journalists' physical safety to be guaranteed by the authorities.<ref name="wsj_engle_beaten" />
[[BBC]] reporter [[Damian Grammaticas]] accused state security of roughing up his crew. He said that they tried to grab equipment from the cameraman and took him 50 yards away into a police van. Grammaticas alleged the police officers then set on him, pulled him by the hair and generally treated him roughly. He also alleged that the police officers then threw the crew into a van and threatened them during their transport to a government office.<ref name="BBC_grammaticas_bashed">{{Cite news | first=Damian | last=Grammaticas | title=Calls for protests in China met with brutality | date=28 February 2011 |publisher=BBC | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12593328 |accessdate=28 February 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wqKpToUM |archivedate=28 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
[[CNN]] reporter [[Eunice Yoon]] reported that a policeman in Wangfujing knocked a camera out of her colleague Jo Ling Kent's hand and six police officers physically forced them into a bank, where they were detained for half an hour.<ref name="CNN_JoKent">{{Cite news | first=Eunice | last=Yoon | title=Getting harassed by the Chinese police | date=28 February 2011 |publisher=CNN | url=http://business.blogs.cnn.com/2011/02/28/getting-harassed-by-the-chinese-police/ |accessdate=28 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wqMVjba1 |archivedate=28 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Yoon remarked after the incident that "there had been no protests for us to cover", and that the incident "show[ed] how incredibly terrified and paranoid the Chinese authorities are".<ref name="business.blogs.cnn.com">{{cite news|author=Posted by: CNN Beijing correspondent, Eunice Yoon |url=http://business.blogs.cnn.com/2011/02/28/getting-harassed-by-the-chinese-police/ |title=Getting harassed by the Chinese police â Business 360 â CNN.com Blogs |publisher=Business.blogs.cnn.com |date=9 March 2011 |accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref> [[Asia Television Limited|ATV]] journalists and a [[Television Broadcasts Limited|TVB]] cameraman were also reportedly briefly detained. ''ATV News'' reported that their footage at the rally site was deleted by officers.<ref name="asiaTV_video_deleted">{{cite web|url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=10&art_id=108559&sid=31459309&con_type=3 |title=Novel ploys keep 'Jasmine' protesters at bay |work=The Standard |location=Hong Kong |accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref> Chinese security forces also visited a few Western journalists in their apartments with nighttime visits asking to behave "cooperatively." Otherwise, they warned, the authorities would refuse to extend their work permits at the end of the year.<ref name="spiegel">{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,751467,00.html |title=An Unwelcome Scent of Jasmine â Chinese Leadership Fears Its Own People |work=Der Spiegel International |location=Hamburg |accessdate=10 April 2011}}</ref>
====Shanghai==== In Shanghai on 27 February, protestors prevented police from arresting an elderly man, when they "reacted instantly and angrily, emitting a guttural roar and surging forward almost as one", according to the ''[[South China Morning Post]]''. Protestors included elderly people and youths documenting the protest with cameras and phones. Some of the core participants appeared to be "deliberately obstructing police efforts to keep the crowd flowing". Other protestors spoke to foreign journalists and joked to each other about police difficulties in stopping "demonstrations that were not actually happening".<ref name="SCMP_unconventional" />
====Hong Kong==== [[File:Voa chinese HK activists 1 20feb11 480.jpg|thumb|right|Some Hong Kong people participated the related protests on 20 February 2011.]] 27 people participated in a "Jasmine Revolution" demonstration in Hong Kong on 27 February, including activists from the Young Civics, they held placards that read "Long live people's power, long live democracy." 40 more participated in another protest outside the offices of the [[Liaison Office of the Central People's Government in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region|Central Government Liaison Office]] in Sheung Wan, for the second time in a week. Participants included Legco member Leung Kwok Hung aka Long Hair and activists from the League of Social Democrats.<ref name="HK_27Feb">{{Cite news | title=Jasmine Revolution 'sluggish' in Hong Kong | date=28 February 2011 |publisher=CNN | url=http://www.cnngo.com/hong-kong/life/jasmine-revolution-sluggish-hong-kong-803484 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wzVpnE8Y |archivedate=6 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
==March 2011== ===6 March=== Beijing was under tight security due to a session of the [[National People's Congress]], and some 180,000 police and 560,000 security volunteers were already on patrol.<ref name=emirates20110313>{{Cite news|url=http://www.emirates247.com/news/world/china-arrests-more-activists-for-urging-protests-2011-03-13-1.367480 |title=China arrests more activists for urging protests |agency=AFP |publisher=Emirates24 |date=13 March 2011 |accessdate=14 March 2011}}</ref> There was a heavy police presence on Sunday in parts of Beijing, Shanghai,<ref name="ThR_6Mar">{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/06/us-china-unrest-idUSTRE7222RA20110306 |title=Beijing says jasmine protest calls doomed to fail |agency=Reuters |accessdate=15 March 2011 |first=Ben |last=Blanchard |date=6 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="CNN_6Mar">{{cite news|author=From Jaime FlorCruz, CNN |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/03/06/china.no.protests/ |title=Chinese official: Protests will 'never happen' in Beijing |publisher=CNN |accessdate=15 March 2011 |date=7 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="MSN_6Mar">{{cite web|last=France |first=Agence |url=http://news.malaysia.msn.com/regional/article.aspx?cp-documentid=4692291 |title=Chinese state media slams calls for protests â Latest news around the world and developments close to home â MSN Malaysia News |publisher=News.malaysia.msn.com |date=6 March 2011 |accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref> Guangzhou and Shenzhen to which protests had been called.<ref name=scmp20110301flowering>Staff Reporters (7 March 2011). "Police out in force again to stop 'jasmine' rallies flowering", ''South China Morning Post''</ref> In Beijing, journalists saw no obvious sign of protesters.<ref name="ThR_6Mar"/> Large contingent of plain-clothed security personnel were reported in and around Wangfujing, Xidan and Zhongguancun.<ref name=scmp20110301flowering/> In Shanghai, most news outlets reported an absence of obvious protestors.<ref name="ThR_6Mar" /><ref name="CNN_6Mar" /><ref name="MSN_6Mar" /> However, [[Deutsche Presse-Agentur]] (DPA) reported around a hundred protestors<ref name="german" /> "surrounded by hundreds of uniformed and plain-clothes police."<ref name="DPA_ShangHai6March_100s">{{Cite news | title=Scores gather for Shanghai 'stroll'; Beijing quiet | date=6 March 2011 | url=http://www.sify.com/news/scores-gather-for-shanghai-stroll-beijing-quiet-news-international-ldgqOiaggcc.html |accessdate=6 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wzQ5FOLW |archivedate=6 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
There were yet more reports of foreign journalists being detained in Shanghai,<ref name=scmp20110301flowering/><ref name="15_journalists">{{Cite news | title=China detains 15 more foreign journalists | date=6 March 2011 |work=The Times of India |location=India | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/china/China-detains-15-more-foreign-journalists/articleshow/7639722.cms |accessdate=7 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> leading to sharp objections from the Foreign Ministries of Germany<ref name="german">{{Cite news | last=dpa/bk | title=Stern journalist detained in China | date=6 March 2011 | publisher=[[The Local]] Germany's news in English | url=http://www.thelocal.de/national/20110306-33535.html |accessdate=7 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wzRt9urT |archivedate=6 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> and Australia.<ref name="australian">{{Cite news | first=Michael | last=Sainsbury | title=Australian government condemns violent crackdown on media | date=7 March 2011 |work=The Australian | url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/media/australian-government-condemns-violent-crackdown-on-media/story-e6frg996-1226016763337 |accessdate=7 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wzRzxBGm |archivedate=6 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
Members of the [[League of Social Democrats]] tried to place a branch of [[Jasminum polyanthum|jasmine]] in front of the [[Central Government Offices]] in Hong Kong.<ref name="DPA_HK1k">{{Cite news | title =More than 1,000 march to protest Hong Kong's rich-poor divide| publisher=[[Monsters and Critics]]/[[Deutsche Presse-Agentur|DPA]] | url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/asiapacific/news/article_1623976.php/More-than-1-000-march-to-protest-Hong-Kong-s-rich-poor-divide |accessdate=6 March 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wzUWEt7E |archivedate=6 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
===13 March=== According to Deutsche Presse-Agentur, there were several hundred police in the Wangfujing and Xidan districts in Beijing, including uniformed police with dogs, paramilitary police, plain-clothes police, special forces units and security guards.<ref name="dpa_13march">{{Cite news | title=China keeps heavy security on fourth "Jasmine" day | date=13 March 2011 | publisher=[[Monsters and Critics]] |agency=[[Deutsche Presse-Agentur|DPA]] | url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/asiapacific/news/article_1625668.php/China-keeps-heavy-security-on-fourth-Jasmine-day |accessdate=13 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> More than 40 police were present at the Peace Cinema in Shanghai.<ref name="dpa_13march" /> According to [[Agence France-Presse]], "there was no massive police presence [at Wangfujing] as seen on previous Sundays."<ref name=emirates20110313/>
===20 March=== In Beijing, hundreds of police were present at some of the eight proposed "strolling" protest locations in commercial areas and some police cars were present at entries to some of the 20 university sites proposed for protests.<ref name="monster_20March_100s">{{cite news | title=Beijing screens more "jasmine" sites but no sign of protest | date=21 March 2011 | publisher=Monsters and Critics |agency=Deutsche Presse-Agentur | url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/asiapacific/news/article_1627420.php/Beijing-screens-more-jasmine-sites-but-no-sign-of-protest |accessdate=21 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xMIK4iAb |archivedate=21 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> ==Government reaction== ===Arrests=== {{See also|2011 crackdown on dissidents in the People's Republic of China}} [[File:Jiang Tianyong.jpg|thumb|Jiang Tianyong (Chin. æ±å¤©å), a [[human rights]] activist and lawyer, detained for a few hours on 20 February.<ref name="AP_27Febplans" />]] [[File:Ran Yunfei.JPG|thumb|Blogger [[Ran Yunfei]] charged with [[inciting subversion of state power]]]] About 35 leading Chinese activists have been arrested or detained by authorities<ref name=emirates20110313/> including a leading [[Sichuan]] human rights activist [[Chen Wei (dissident)|Chen Wei]] ({{zh|éå«}}),<ref name="LATimes_PRC_26Feb">{{Cite news | first=David | last=Pierson | title=Online call for protests in China prompts crackdown | date=26 February 2011 |work=Los Angeles Times | url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fgw-china-crackdown-20110227,0,4764714.story?track=rss |accessdate=26 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wnIe28Bl |archivedate=26 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> [[Tiananmen Square protests of 1989|Tiananmen Square protest]] student leader, [[Ding Mao]] ({{zh|ä¸ç}}),<ref name="LATimes_PRC_26Feb"/> well-known blogger [[Ran Yunfei]] ({{zh|åäºé£}}), and [[Teng Biao]] ({{zh|æ»å½ª}}) of Open Constitutional Initiative.<ref name="AP_27Febplans">{{Cite news | title=Organizers urge sustained street protests in China | date=23 February 2011 | publisher=[[Mercury News]] |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] | url=http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_17457973?nclick_check=1 |accessdate=26 February 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wlyrzY1r |archivedate=25 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref name=asiaone20110211>{{cite web|url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/Latest%2BNews/Asia/Story/A1Story20110221-264556.html |title=Chinese police snuff out planned 'Jasmine Revolution' |publisher=News.asiaone.com |accessdate=22 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="bbcnames">Bbc.co.uk. "[http://www.bbc.co.uk/zhongwen/trad/china/2011/02/110220_brief_china_police.shtml bbc.co.uk]." ''é¾ç¾ä¸­å½ç»´æäººå£«è¢«æå¤±è¸ª.'' Retrieved on 21 February 2011.</ref> Chengdu-based activist and legal advisor Li Shuangde ({{zh|æåå¾·}}), who was sentenced to four months in prison in on charges of credit card fraud, is considered the first to have been sentenced on "jasmine" related charges.<ref>John Kennedy," [http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/06/01/china-first-jasmine-sentence-handed-down/ China: First âJasmine' Sentence Handed Down]," Global Voices Online, June 1, 2011</ref><ref name="lsd02">Human Rights in China, "[http://www.hrichina.org/content/5481 Sichuan Barefoot Lawyer Speaks Out against Trumped-up Charge]," July 22, 2011</ref> Since the 19 February protest announcement, more than a hundred people have been summoned or questioned by police,<ref name="harshest_crackdown">{{Cite news | first=Tania | last=Branigan | title=China's jasmine revolution: police but no protesters line streets of Beijing | date=27 February 2011 |work=The Guardian |location=UK | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/27/china-jasmine-revolution-beijing-police |accessdate=27 February 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wotLedbP |archivedate=27 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> and up to 200 people are subject to reinforced supervision or house arrest.<ref name="tagesschau">{{cite web|url=http://tagesschau.vo.llnwd.net/d3/audio/2011/0407/AU-20110407-1518-2501.ogg |title=China warns not to interfere with detention of Ai Weiwei |publisher=Tagesschau |date=7 April 2011 |accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref>
The highest-profile arrest is [[Ai Weiwei]], who was taken into police custody on 3 April in Beijing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/chinese-artist-ai-wei-wei-arrested-in-latest-government-crackdown/2011/04/03/AFHB5PVC_story.html |title=Chinese artist Ai Weiwei arrested in ongoing government crackdown |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=6 April 2011 |date=3 April 2011 |first=Greg |last=Jaffe}}</ref> Amid Boxun's online campaign, Ai had posted on his Twitter account on 24 February: "I didnât care about jasmine at first, but people who are scared by jasmine sent out information about how harmful jasmine is often, which makes me realize that jasmine is what scares them the most. What a jasmine!"<ref name=wpost20110403>Richburg, Keith B. (3 April 2011). [http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/chinese-artist-ai-wei-wei-arrested-in-latest-government-crackdown/2011/04/03/AFHB5PVC_story.html "Chinese artist Ai Weiwei arrested in latest government crackdown"], ''Washington Post''</ref><ref>Twitter (8 April 2011). http://twitter.com/aiww/status/40606428100177920</ref> Ai's studio was raided by police, who took away computer equipment; a number of his entourage were also arrested by police.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/artanddesign/2011/apr/03/ai-weiwei-detained-chinese-police|title=Ai Weiwei detained by Chinese police|work=The Guardian |location=UK | |first1=Tania|last1=Branigan|first2=Jonathan|last2=Watts|date=3 April 2011}}</ref> Analysts and other activists said Ai had been widely thought to be untouchable, but Nicholas Bequelin from Human Rights Watch suggested that his arrest, calculated to send the message that no-one would be immune, must have had the approval of someone in the top leadership.<ref>Clem, Will & Choi Chi-yuk (6 April 2011). "Beijing's silence an ominous signal", ''South China Morning Post''</ref> While state media originally reported on 6 April that Ai was arrested at the airport because "his departure procedures were incomplete,"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.huanqiu.com/opinion/editorial/2011-04/641187.html|title=Law will not concede before maverick|publisher=Global Times}}</ref> the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on 7 April that Ai was under investigation for 'economic crimes'.<ref>{{cite news | title = Chinese artist Ai Weiwei held for 'economic crimes' | date = 7 April 2011 |publisher=BBC | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12994785 }}</ref>
===Censorship=== {{see also|Censorship in the People's Republic of China|Internet censorship in the People's Republic of China}} [[China Mobile]] and [[China Unicom]] blocked the word "jasmine".<ref>{{cite web|author=WL Central |url=http://wlcentral.org/node/1339 |title=2011-02-19 China calls for a Jasmine Revolution: Summary: It didn't work. #CNJasmine2011 #cn220 #OpChina |publisher=Wikileaks |date=19 February 2011 |accessdate=22 February 2011}}</ref> Searches for "jasmine" were also blocked<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/220206/china_blocks_microblogs_for_jasmine_revolution.html |title=China Blocks Microblogs for 'Jasmine Revolution' |work=PC World |date=20 February 2011 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref> on China's largest microblog, [[Sina Weibo]], and status updates with the word on Chinese social networking site [[Renren]] were met with an error message and a warning to refrain from postings with "political, sensitive ... or other inappropriate content."<ref name="yahoo1"/>
Since the word "Jasmine" was forbidden in the Chinese blogosphere, millions of netizens used the term "two conferences" instead, a widely used expression in the official news originally pointing to the two conferences "Fourth Session of the Eleventh National People's Congress" and "Fourth Session of the Eleventh CPPCC" happening in March in Beijing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blogotariat.com/node/213917 |title=The 'Jasmine Revolution' |work=Blogotariat |date=10 April 2011 |accessdate=13 April 2011}}</ref>
On 25 February, several foreign journalists were contacted by police and told that they could not conduct interviews without applying for permission.<ref name="LATimes_PRC_26Feb" /> Regulations issued by the Chinese government forbid entry by foreign reporters into the Wangfujing shopping district in Beijing or the Peopleâs Park in central Shanghai without a special permit. Enforcement of the new rules on Sunday 28 February resulted in beating of one camera operator and detention of several reporters for several hours before their release and confiscation of their materials.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/02/world/asia/02china.html |title=Chinese Move to Stop Reporting on Protests|author=Andrew Jacobs |date=1 March 2011 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=1 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Ananth Krishnan |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article1501081.ece |title=News / International : Chinese government places media restrictions after protest threat |publisher=The Hindu |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=15 March 2011 |location=Chennai, India}}</ref>
Following calls for a "Jasmine Revolution" on Twitter, Chinese users of Twitter began to notice a number of new accounts, sometimes using the names or images of Chinese democracy activists. Tweets by the new accounts took a hostile position to calls for demonstrations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://chinadigitaltimes.net/2011/02/fifty-cent-tweets-a-collection-of-anti-jasmine-revolution-messages/ |title=Remarkable Quotes from the Fifty Cent Party: Anti-Jasmine Revolution Tweets |date=28 February 2011 |publisher=China Digital Times |accessdate=1 March 2011}}</ref>
In late March, [[Google]] stated that intermittent problems with [[Gmail]] in the PRC constitute "a government blockage carefully designed to look like the problem is with Gmail". ''[[PC Mag]]'' attributed the blockage to the calls for a "Jasmine Revolution" in the PRC.<ref name="pcmag_gmail_obstructed">{{cite web| last =Albanesius| first =Chloe| title =China Blocks Gmail to Stop Protests| publisher=[[PC Mag]]| date =21 March 2011| url =http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2382310,00.asp | accessdate =21 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xMJ5Ay1D |archivedate=21 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
===Other security measures=== More than 20 Chinese cities, including [[Tianjin]], [[Chengdu]] and [[Guangzhou]], stepped up security measures, with state security, police and armed forces ordered to stand by in case of emergency.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://topics.scmp.com/news/china-news-watch/article/Hundreds-join-Jasmine-Revolution |title=Hundreds join 'Jasmine Revolution' |work=South China Morning Post |date=21 February 2011 |accessdate=22 February 2011}}</ref> [[CPC General Secretary]] and President [[Hu Jintao]] delivered a speech in the [[Central Party School]] on 19 February instructing senior management to better manage social problems and internet incitement.<ref name="yahoo1">{{Cite news|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/as_china_jasmine_revolution |title=China stamps out attempt at Mideast-style protests |agency=AP |publisher=Yahoo! News |date=21 February 2011 |accessdate=22 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8247574-china-blocks-microblogs-for-jasmine-revolution-china-tries-to-stamp-out-jasmine-revolution |title=China Blocks Microblogs for 'Jasmine Revolution; China tries to stamp out âJasmine Revolutionâ |publisher=Allvoices.com |accessdate=22 February 2011}}</ref>
Chinese artist [[Ai Weiwei]] said that there were tight controls on university students to prevent students from participating in protests. He alleged that teachers had received "a certain note ordering them to do their duty, otherwise they will be in trouble, or their school will be in trouble."<ref name="AiWeiWei_universities">{{Cite news | first=Peter | last=Foster | title=Ai Wei Wei: 'growing force behind Jasmine Revolution very strong' | date=7 March 2011 | url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/8366009/Ai-Wei-Wei-growing-force-behind-Jasmine-Revolution-very-strong.html |accessdate=13 March 2011 |deadurl=no | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref>
===Jasmine flower ban=== On 10 May 2011, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that Beijing police had banned the sale of [[jasmine]] flowers at various flower markets, causing wholesale prices to collapse. Some vendors stated that Beijing police wanted written assurances that no jasmine flowers shall be sold in their stalls. The Guangxi Jasmine Development and Investment Company, organisers of the China International Jasmine Cultural Festival, said that officials cancelled the 2011 summer festival.<ref name="NYT_jasmine_flower_banned">{{cite news | first=Andrew | last=Jacobs |coauthors= Jonathan Ansfield | title=Catching Scent of Revolution, China Moves to Snip Jasmine | date=10 May 2011 |work=New York Times | url= http://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/11/world/asia/11jasmine.html|accessdate=28 May 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5z1eRkXOh |archivedate=28 May 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
==Reactions== ===Domestic=== [[File:Voa chinese Zhao-Qizheng press 23feb11 480.jpg|thumb|alt=|Zhao Qizheng said 'No Jasmine Revolution']] A high level Chinese government official Zhao Qizheng said, on 23 February, that the probability of China having a "Jasmine Revolution" is "absurd and unrealistic". He also said that "although there are many problems in China right now, the government is doing the best it can to try and combat these problems instead of ignoring them. The government reveals its own problems to the public and tries to deal with it. This type of government is strong and will move forward."
Premier [[Wen Jiabao]] participated in a [[web chat]] on 27 February that [[France 24]] described as an "apparent bid to defuse" the call for weekly gatherings.<ref name="webjiabao_webchat" /> In the webchat, he promised to deal with inflation, corruption, lack of housing, property speculation.<ref name="webjiabao_webchat">{{Cite news | title=China's Wen addresses concerns amid protest call | date=27 February 2011 | publisher=[[France 24]] | url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110227-chinas-wen-addresses-concerns-amid-protest-call |accessdate=28 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5woxC2xFU |archivedate=27 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref name="harshest_crackdown" /> ''[[The Financial Times]]'' (FT) claimed that the web chat was "announced abruptly late on [26 February] and appeared to be timed to coincide with the planned protests."<ref name="FT_blanketed">{{Cite news | author=Hille, Kathrin & Waldmeir, Patti | title=China muffles calls for democracy protests | work=Financial Times| url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/e7a66d8a-422d-11e0-8b34-00144feabdc0.html |accessdate=28 February 2011 |deadurl=no }} ''[http://www.webcitation.org/5wp1bYl0z partial archive 27 February 2011]''</ref> It added that with the web chat, "state media blanketed the nation over the internet, television and radio on Sunday morning with two hours of remarks by Wen Jiabao".<ref name="FT_blanketed" /> [[China News Service|China News]] said that the webchat had been planned in advance; similar webchats had taken place on 20 June 2008 and 27 February 2010.<ref name="ChNews_innocentwebchat">{{Cite news | language =[[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]] | title=æ»ççº¦ä¼ç½åæ¸ææ¯ä¾ ç½ç»é®æ¿èæä¸­å½æ¿åé£æ¯ | date=26 February 2011 | publisher=[[China News Service|China News]] | url=http://www.chinanews.com/gn/2011/02-27/2870538.shtml |accessdate=28 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wozhZghZ |archivedate=27 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
{{quote box |quote="Political reform offers a guarantee for economic reform. Without political reform, economic reform cannot succeed, and the achievements we have made may be lost," he said yesterday. "It is only with reform that the party and the country will enjoy continuous vigour and vitality."<ref name=scmp20110315wen>Shi Jiangtao (15 Mar 2011). "Political reform is needed, Wen insists", ''South China Morning Post''</ref> |source=Wen Jiabao at NCPCC on 14 March 2011 |align = right |width = 33% |border = 1px |fontsize = 88% |bgcolor = #E6E6FA }}
====Wu Bangguo's five "No"==== Addressing the meeting of the National People's Congress, its chairman [[Wu Bangguo]] dismissed any notion of political reform, saying that Western-style democracy would have dire consequences, and that any loosening of the Party's hold on power could undermine stability and risk domestic strife, and he also:"advocated the five noes: no multi-party election; no diversified guiding principles, no separation of powers, no federal system and no privatization".<ref name=scmp20110311>Shi Jiangtao (11 Mar 2011). "Beijing slams door on political reform", ''South China Morning Post''</ref><ref>http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/opinion/china-prepares-for-war-without-gun-smoke/435812 The Jakarta Globe China Prepares for 'War Without Gun Smoke' Ching Cheong â Straits Times Indonesia | 16 April 2011</ref>
Wu, who belongs to the conservative faction of the leadership, said: "We have made a solemn declaration that we will not employ a system of multiple parties holding office in rotation; diversify our guiding thought; separate executive, legislative and judicial powers; use a bicameral or federal system; or carry out privatisation." Analysts said the warnings were aimed at consolidating the party's power, in reaction to calls for liberal democracy in Egypt, Tunisia and Libya.<ref name=scmp20110311/> On the other hand, the more liberal Wen Jiabao said that economic and political reform, safeguarding social equity and justice were major factors behind China's success. He also rejected comparisons with Egypt and Tunisia, and reiterated his support for greater democracy and public supervision, saying economic development alone could not solve the problems of the mainland's development.
===International=== ''Time'' suggested that though there are many similarities between the complaints [[2010â2011 Middle East and North Africa protests|voiced by the people in the Middle East and North Africa]] and those voiced by the Chinese people, the state's tighter grip on the country's media, Internet and other communication forums pose difficulties for anyone trying to organise mass demonstrations.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{Cite news|agency=AP |author=ANITA CHANG |url=http://www.time.com/t ime/world/article/0,8599,2052847,00.html |title=China Suppresses 'Jasmine Revolution' |work=TIME |date= 20 Feb. 2011 |accessdate=22 February 2011}}</ref>
The ''Wall Street Journal'' said that the online protest appeal could compound apparent concern among [[Chinese Communist Party]] leaders that the recent uprisings against authoritarian governments in the Middle East and North Africa could inspire similar unrest in China.<ref>{{cite news|last=Page |first=Jeremy |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703498804576156203874160350.html |title=Call for Protests Unnerves Beijing |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=28 February 2011 |accessdate=22 February 2011}}</ref>
[[CNN]] journalist Eunice Yoon and her news crew headed out to Wangfujing to cover the "response to anonymous calls on the Internet to stage protests and begin a Tunisia-style "Jasmine Revolution" in China",<ref name="business.blogs.cnn.com"/> was physically handled by police in Beijing on 27 February at arrival near the protest site. She wrote: "What makes China's treatment of the international press so bewildering is that there had been no protests for us to cover here..... My own experience and those of my colleagues show how incredibly terrified and paranoid the Chinese authorities are of any anti-government movement forming in China."<ref name="CNN_JoKent" />
Following the arrests of approximately 15 foreign journalists on 6 March, ''[[The Australian]]'' described the attempts at organising a "Jasmine Revolution" in China as "the biggest showdown between Chinese authorities and foreign media in more than two decades."<ref name="australian" />
''[[The Atlantic]]'' reported that [[Hillary Clinton]] thinks the Chinese government is "scared" of the Arab rising. "They're worried, and they are trying to stop history, which is a [[Snipe hunt|fool's errand]]. They cannot do it. But they're going to hold it off as long as possible."<ref>Goldberg, Jeffrey (10 May 2011). [http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2011/05/hillary-clinton-chinese-system-is-doomed-leaders-on-a-fools-errand/238591/ Hillary Clinton: Chinese System Is Doomed, Leaders on a 'Fool's Errand'], ''The Atlantic''</ref>
'''about Leadership dispute''' It is said that this event was taken advantage of some oversea acitivists who want to say they are the leader of this event and get benefit from this leadership position, like funding from American anti-Chinese groups.Some people claimed that this event is not initiated by those oversea people who made a website about Jasmine revolution of China. They criticized them in trying to grasp the effort to their own. <ref>{{cite web|last=anonymous|first=anonymous|title=Back of Jasmine Revolution|url=http://bbs.wolfax.com/thread-14137-1-1.html|work=Back of Jasmine Revolution}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|last=anonymous|first=anoymous|title=Why people are trying to be leader of Jasmine Revolution|url=http://www.duping.net/XHC/show.php?bbs=11&post=1134650}}</ref>
===Taiwan protests=== On 24 February, whilst visiting [[Kaohsiung]] to discuss economic ties between the People's Republic of China and Taiwan (ROC), [[Chen Yun-lin]], Chairman of Mainland China's [[Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits]],<ref name="sinoda1">{{cite web|url=http://www.sinodaily.com/reports/Taiwan_protesters_throw_flowers_at_China_envoy_999.html |title=Taiwan protesters throw flowers at China envoy |publisher=Sinodaily.com |accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref> was mobbed by about 200 protesters at Kaohsiung Harbor. Some protesters threw [[chrysanthemum]] flowers at him (as Jasmine flowers were not in season), while others tried to deliver plastic jasmine flowers and juice to him.<ref name="sinoda1" /><ref name="ya0225">{{cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2011/02/25/2003496737 |title=Protesters throw flowers at Chen Yunlin |work=Taipei Times |date=8 March 2011 |accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref> Earlier, at [[Kaohsiung Station]], Chen had already encountered two groups of demonstrators, one supporting [[Taiwanese independence]] and another [[Chinese unification]]. Police claimed that the groups both numbered about 50 people.<ref name="sinoda1" /> About 300 [[Falun Gong]] followers also staged a protest.<ref name="sinoda1" /> On 8 March, the [[Democratic Progressive Party]] released a strongly worded statement condemning the use of force against participants of the âJasmine Revolutionâ in China. The statement urged the government to incorporate values of democracy and human rights into agreements with Beijing when promoting cross-strait ties to encourage âChinaâs democratic transformation.â<ref>Vincent Y. Chao (10 Mar 2011). [http://taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2011/03/10/2003497829 "DPP condemns Chinaâs crackdown on protesters"], Page 3, ''Taipei Times''</ref>
